Description: Gold amuletic figure representing the dwarf leonine god Bes; repoussé technique on gold plate; figured naked, slightly squatting with hands on his hips; with lion ears and wearing his characteristic plumed headdress; standing on a plinth of unidentified shape (capital?); some features detailed with incisions, such as the chevron pattern of the headdress feathers.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Egyptian Museum, Cairo. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

A number of gold plate amulets and figures were found in a 1st century AD deposit in Naukratis. This may, however, be an earlier example. As possible parallels, see British Museum 1886,0401.1765 and Cairo Museum JE26779.

Found on the surface of chamber 27 in the Hellenion, see Hogarth 1899, 34. Hogarth also mentions the find in his 1899 diary: 'In morning a little gold Bes [...] found by a woman who grumbled at 12 francs. However it kept work alive at N. end' (entry of Thursday March 2nd). He probably acquired it from a sebbakh-digger working in the area of the Hellenion. Another gold Bes amulet made with repoussé technique is Brooklyn Museum 08.480.208, dated to the Late and Ptolemaic period.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OK.001) (Phase 3)
